instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2879: What is 820-2879? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.U5701: What is U5701? this is the keyboard controller chip that takes the keyboard and trackpad input and turns it into a USB device signal for the machine to process. If replacing a keyboard doesnâ€™t fix an issue with keys not typing, check all traces between keyboard connector and this IC. This chip has programming so it must be replaced from a similar, ideally identical board. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b
threads.message: Customer upgraded his computer and i purchased his old one. It boots up just fine but when i when to option boot to test asd or to reinstall os it will not work. just continues boot. it wont reset pram either. Ive tried with new keyboard and usb apple keyboard. neither work.  ive tried to reset smc but that didn't solve.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b
threads.message: Must use PC8500 RAM, at least one PC8500 RAM stick should be in there, the other one will not matter.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b
threads.message: The ram is the ram that came with the computer. its 8500s ram. should i change it?  just wondering why ram would mess with option boot.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b
threads.message: Not efi locked.  just will not option boot or pram reset.  if i put in a working hdd everything works out.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b
threads.message: Swap BIOS from another board to rule that out. Also disconnect airport cable to rule that out.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b
threads.message: replaced <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> and disconnected airport cable.  still no option boot or pram reset.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b
threads.message: Disconnected everything and just use a USB keyboard? If not working remove <RESISTOR>R5701</RESISTOR>/02 to isolate <CHIP>U5701</CHIP> from messing with USB.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b
threads.message: okay so after removing <RESISTOR>R5701</RESISTOR>/02 usb keyboard pram reset works. i'm assuming i need to replace <CHIP>U5701</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b
threads.message: That would seem like a plan.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b
threads.message: all good now duke. thanks for the help. one quick question.  should i put the old bios back on or can i leave the swapped on?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b
threads.message: Does not really matter, only serial number is wrong now. No ME issues as is MCP platform.
